results.question: If an insured person takes treatment for arthritis at home because no hospital beds are available, under what circumstances would these expenses NOT be covered, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required?
results.answer: Information not found in the document. The provided context does not specify whether expenses for treatment of arthritis at home would be covered if no hospital beds are available.

results.question: A claim was lodged for expenses on a prosthetic device after a hip replacement surgery. The hospital bill also includes the cost of a walker and a lumbar belt post-discharge. Which items are payable?
results.answer: The prosthetic device after a hip replacement surgery is payable, but the walker and lumbar belt post-discharge are not payable (based on the information provided in Context 1 and 2).

results.question: An insured's child (a dependent above 18 but under 26, unemployed and unmarried) requires dental surgery after an accident. What is the claim admissibility, considering both eligibility and dental exclusions, and what is the process for this specific scenario?
results.answer: The claim for dental surgery after an accident for a dependent child (unemployed and unmarried, aged between 18 and 26) is admissible, provided the necessary documents are submitted as per the claim process, but it may be subject to dental exclusions as per the policy terms.

results.question: If an insured undergoes Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM) during brain surgery, and also needs ICU care in a city over 1 million population, how are the respective expenses limited according to modern treatments, critical care definition, and policy schedule?
results.answer: The expenses for Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM) during brain surgery are limited up to the category/limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance, while ICU charges are limited up to the category/limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance for cities over 1 million population, according to modern treatments and critical care definition in the policy document. (Information found in Context 1, 3, and 8)

results.question: A policyholder requests to add their newly-adopted child as a dependent. The child is 3 years old. What is the process and under what circumstances may the insurer refuse cover for the child, referencing eligibility and addition/deletion clauses?
results.answer: The insurer may refuse cover for the newly-adopted child if the child is not within the eligible age range (usually up to 26 years old, unless still dependent) or if additional premium is not paid for the change in group size, as per the addition/deletion clauses in the policy.

results.question: If a person is hospitalised for a day care cataract procedure and after two weeks develops complications requiring 5 days of inpatient care in a non-network hospital, describe the claim process for both events, referencing claim notification timelines and document requirements.
results.answer: The Insured Person should first pay for the day care cataract procedure up-front, then submit necessary documents to the TPA within the prescribed time limit for reimbursement. For the subsequent 5 days of inpatient care in a non-network hospital, the Insured Person should make payment up-front and submit the necessary documents to the TPA within the prescribed time limit for reimbursement, as well.

results.question: An insured mother with cover opted for maternity is admitted for a complicated C-section but sadly, the newborn expires within 24 hours requiring separate intensive care. What is the claim eligibility for the newborn's treatment expenses, referencing definitions, exclusions, and newborn cover terms?
results.answer: Information not found in the document regarding the claim eligibility for the newborn's treatment expenses.

results.question: If a policyholder files a claim for inpatient psychiatric treatment, attaching as supporting documents a prescription from a general practitioner and a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist, is this sufficient? Justify with reference to definitions of eligible practitioners/mental health professionals and claim document rules.
results.answer: Information not found in the document. The provided context does not specify whether a prescription from a general practitioner and a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist are sufficient for a claim for inpatient psychiatric treatment.

results.question: A patient receives oral chemotherapy in a network hospital and requests reimbursement for ECG electrodes and gloves used during each session. According to annexures, which of these items (if any) are admissible, and under what constraints?
results.answer: ECG electrodes are payable, but only up to 5 electrodes are required for every case visiting OT or ICU. Gloves are not payable. (Context 4)

results.question: A hospitalized insured person develops an infection requiring post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses 20 days after discharge. Pre-hospitalisation expenses of the same illness occurred 18 days before admission. Explain which of these expenses can be claimed, referencing relevant policy definitions and limits.
results.answer: The insured person can claim the post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses as they occurred within the pre-defined number of days (immediately after discharge) and are related to the same illness for which an in-patient hospitalization claim was accepted. However, the pre-hospitalization expenses incurred 18 days before admission cannot be claimed as they exceed the pre-hospitalization period defined in the policy.

results.question: If a dependent child turns 27 during the policy period but the premium was paid at the beginning of the coverage year, how long does their coverage continue, and when is it terminated with respect to eligibility and deletion protocols?
results.answer: Information not found in the document. The policy document does not specify the duration of coverage for a dependent child who turns 27 during the policy period, nor does it mention the deletion protocol in such a case.

results.question: A procedure was conducted in a hospital where the insured opted for a single private room costing more than the allowed room rent limit. Diagnostic and specialist fees are billed separately. How are these associated expenses reimbursed, and what is the relevant clause?
results.answer: The reimbursement for the associated expenses (room rent exceeding the limit, diagnostic, and specialist fees) in this scenario will be subject to a proportionate deduction, as per Note 1 of Clause III.A.1.

results.question: Describe the course of action if a claim is partly rejected due to lack of required documentation, the insured resubmits the documents after 10 days, and then wishes to contest a final rejection. Refer to claim timeline rules and grievance procedures.
results.answer: If a claim is partly rejected due to lack of required documentation and the insured resubmits the documents after 10 days, the claim will be reassessed within 15 days of the receipt of the last necessary document. If the claim is still rejected, the insured may contest the decision within 15 days from the date of receipt of the claims decision, and can follow the grievance procedures outlined in the document, such as contacting the company through their website, toll-free number, email, or by writing to the Customer Care Department. If the insured is not satisfied with the redressal of grievance through these methods, they may approach the Insurance Ombudsman of the

results.question: An insured person is hospitalized for 22 hours for a minimally invasive surgery under general anesthesia. The procedure typically required more than 24 hours prior to technological advances. Is their claim eligible? Cite the relevant category and its requirements.
results.answer: Information not found in the document. The context does not provide specific details about minimally invasive surgeries or their duration requirements.

results.question: When the insured is hospitalized in a town with less than 1 million population, what are the minimum infrastructure requirements for the hospital to qualify under this policy, and how are they different in metropolitan areas?
results.answer: In towns with less than 10,00,000 population, the hospital must have at least 10 in-patient beds, while in all other places, it must have at least 15 in-patient beds to qualify under this policy. The requirement is different in metropolitan areas. (Information found in context 1)

results.question: A group employer wishes to add a new employee, their spouse, and sibling as insured persons mid-policy. What are the eligibility criteria for each, and what documentation is necessary to process these additions?
results.answer: The new employee, their spouse, and sibling can be added as insured persons under the policy if they meet the eligibility criteria: the employee must be an employee of the policyholder, the spouse must be the employee's legal spouse or life partner, and the sibling must be unmarried and unemployed. Documentation necessary to process these additions includes an endorsement request, additional premium, and required information/documents/premium as assessed by the underwriter.

results.question: Summarize the coverage for robotic surgery for cancer, including applicable sub-limits, when done as a day care procedure vs inpatient hospitalization.
results.answer: The policy covers robotic surgeries for cancer, including malignancies, with sub-limits specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance for both day care procedures and inpatient hospitalization.

results.question: If an accident necessitates air ambulance evacuation with subsequent inpatient admission, what steps must be followed for both pre-authorization and claims assessment? Discuss mandatory requirements and documentation.
results.answer: For air ambulance evacuation and subsequent inpatient admission due to an accident, pre-authorization is required from the insurer, and the claim must be assessed with necessary documentation such as air ambulance ticket for a registered service provider and intimation of the claim to the insurer's call center or in writing.

results.question: Explain how the policy treats waiting periods for a specific illness (e.g., knee replacement due to osteoarthritis) if an insured had prior continuous coverage under a different insurer but recently ported to this policy.
results.answer: If the insured had prior continuous coverage under a different insurer and recently ported to this policy, the waiting period for a specific illness (e.g., knee replacement due to osteoarthritis) would be reduced to the extent of prior coverage, as per IRDAI guidelines on portability.

results.question: If a doctor prescribes an imported medication not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment, will the expense be covered? Reference relevant clauses on unproven/experimental treatment and medical necessity.
results.answer: Information not found in the document regarding coverage for imported medications not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment. The document does not specify whether such expenses would be covered under the unproven/experimental treatment or medical necessity clauses.

results.question: A member of a non-employer group policy dies during the policy period. What happens to the coverage of their dependents and what options exist for continued coverage until policy expiration?
results.answer: In the event of a member's death during the policy period, coverage for their dependents continues, and they have the option to maintain coverage until policy expiration by transferring the policy to another insurer under portability guidelines, if they have been continuously covered without any lapses under any health insurance product offered by the company (Information not found in the document).

results.question: For claims involving implanted devices (e.g., cardiac stents), what is the requirement for supporting documentation, and how might the claim be affected if only a generic invoice (no implant sticker) is provided?
results.answer: For claims involving implanted devices, the requirement for supporting documentation includes an original invoice with an implant sticker for the specific implant used during the surgery (e.g., lens sticker in cataract surgery, stent invoice and sticker in angioplasty surgery). If only a generic invoice is provided, the claim might be affected and may not be fully settled. (Information not found in the document regarding the specific consequences of providing only a generic invoice.)

results.question: A spouse suffers a serious accident and is incapacitated, requiring prolonged home nursing after discharge. Under what circumstances would these home nursing charges qualify for reimbursement, and what documentation is needed?
results.answer: Information not found in the document regarding the specific circumstances under which home nursing charges would qualify for reimbursement. However, it is stated that charges must be incurred on Medically Necessary Treatment and follow the written Medical Advice. The necessary documentation needed would typically include medical reports and invoices for the nursing services.

results.question: In the case of a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, what is the procedure for claim settlement, coordination, and required documentation?
results.answer: In a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, the primary Insurer shall seek the details of other available policies, coordinate with other Insurers, and settle the balance amount, provided a written request for the same has been submitted by the Insured Person (Context 6.ii).

results.question: Suppose the insured's hospitalization was for evaluation and all tests and imaging were negative, leading to a decision for no treatment. Are these expenses claimable? Discuss using definitions and exclusions.
results.answer: Information not found in the document. The document does not provide specific details about the claimability of expenses for hospitalization for evaluation purposes without treatment.

results.question: How does the insurer treat requests to update the nominee after the sudden demise of the previous nominee and in the absence of any prior endorsement for nominee change?
results.answer: Information not found in the document. The policy document does not specify how the insurer treats requests to update the nominee after the sudden demise of the previous nominee and in the absence of any prior endorsement for nominee change.

results.question: List scenarios where prostheses or medical appliances are NOT covered, even if associated with hospitalization. Use definitions and exclusions for your justification.
results.answer: Prostheses or medical appliances are not covered if they are not required intra-operatively for the illness/injury for which the Insured Person was hospitalized, as per Exclusion 19 in the document.

results.question: If a patient receives inpatient care for mental illness from an AYUSH hospital that is not registered locally but has qualified practitioners, will expenses be reimbursed? Why or why not?
results.answer: Information not found in the document. The provided context does not specify whether expenses for mental illness treatment at an AYUSH hospital that is not registered locally but has qualified practitioners will be reimbursed.

results.question: An insured requests cashless facility for hospitalization at a network provider and subsequently changes their treatment plan resulting in a higher estimate. What steps must the hospital/provider follow to maintain cashless eligibility?
results.answer: The hospital/provider must obtain a fresh authorization letter from the TPA for the changed treatment plan to maintain cashless eligibility. (Context 4, Clause V.7)

results.question: If a claim for pre-hospitalization expenses is submitted before the main inpatient hospitalization claim has been approved, how is this processed according to the assessment sequence outlined in the policy?
results.answer: Information not found in the document regarding the processing of a pre-hospitalization claim before the main inpatient hospitalization claim has been approved.
